key_points: Amrita Bhagwandin's home in Queens was severely damaged by flooding from Hurricane Ida, requiring costly repairs.
Many New Yorkers affected by Hurricane Ida report insufficient aid from FEMA more than three months post-storm.
Homeowners and renters face various challenges, with some seeking to sell their damaged properties and others needing renovations or new housing.
The storm highlighted the ongoing housing crisis in New York City, worsened by climate change.
Victims express frustration with the lack of urgency from politicians and agencies in addressing their needs.
More than 88,700 New Yorkers applied for FEMA assistance, with $163.7 million approved by December 3.
Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Jamaal Bowman have called for more substantial aid from FEMA.
FEMA extended the deadline for financial assistance applications following advocacy.
Governor Kathy Hochul extended the deadline for a relief fund for undocumented New Yorkers excluded from FEMA assistance.
Mayor Bill de Blasio promised long-term housing support for storm victims, but specific plans are still under evaluation.
spokespersons: Mercedes Padilla (spokesperson, state Office of New Americans)
Becca Talzek (deputy director, Make the Road New York)
Lauren Bale (spokesperson, Mayor Bill de Blasio)
